issues.text: Whether this Court has jurisdiction to entertain this petition

anchor.surface_text: As a preliminary objection, to the effect that this Court has no jurisdiction to entertain this petition, has been taken on behalf of the respondents and we agree with the same,, it is sufficient if

issues.text: Whether the entire cause of action for the reliefs prayed has arisen within the territorial jurisdiction of this Court

anchor.surface_text: It may be noted that the searches and the seizures in question have taken place in the city of Bombay. Respondents 1 and 2 reside in that city. Their offices are situate in that city. Even the petitioner is residing in that city. The authorisation issued by the 1st respondent under section 132 1  was issued in that city, therefore, prima facie, the entire cause of action has arisen in the city of Bombay. That being so, the reliefs prayed for in the petition, whether considered under sub-Article  1  of Article 226 or under Sub-Article  2  of Article 226, prima facie, fall outside the jurisdiction of this Court.

issues.text: Whether the Central Government is a necessary party to this petition

anchor.surface_text: under sub-Article  1  of Article 226 or under Sub-Article  2  of Article 226, prima facie, fall outside the jurisdiction of this Court. It was urged on behalf of the petitioner that to this petition the Central Government is a necessary party, and, therefore, this Court has jurisdiction to entertain this petition. If the Central Government is a necessary party to this petition, then this Court would have jurisdiction to entertain this petition. Therefore, we have to see whether the Central Government is a necessary party to this petition.

issues.text: Whether the Central Government is a necessary party because the seized money has been appropriated towards arrears and forms part of the Consolidated Fund

anchor.surface_text: Undoubtedly, the Central Government is not a necessary party to the reliefs prayed for as against respondents 1 and 2. That much was not disputed before us. But what was said on behalf of the petitioner is that the money seized by the 2nd respondent at any rate that portion of the money, that had been appropriated towards the tax due from the petitioner, has gone to the Consolidated Fund of India. That Fund is under the control of the Government is a necessary party to this petition.

issues.text: Whether the Central Government is a necessary party to a proceeding challenging the vires of a provision of a Central Act

anchor.surface_text: The next contention taken by Mr. Sharma, learned counsel for the petitioner, is that as in this petition the petitioner is challenging the vires of S. 132 5  of the Income-Tax Act, 1961, the Central Government is a necessary party to such a proceeding. We have not to see whether that contention can be upheld. Our attention has not been drawn to any provision of law prescribing that the Central Government must be made a party to a proceeding in which the validity of a Central Act or any provision therein is called in question. ... It is prescribed in R. 1 of O. 27A of the Civil Procedure Code that in any suit in which it appears to the Court that any such question as is referred in clause  1  of Article 132 read with Article 147 of the Constitution, is involved, the Court shall not proceed to determine that question until after notice has been given to the Attorney General for India

issues.text: Whether the pending application under section 132(11) before the Central Board of Direct Taxes at New Delhi confers jurisdiction on this Court due to the doctrine of merger

anchor.surface_text: The next contention, urged by Mr. Sharma in support of his contention is that as against the decision of the 1st respondent, his client has filed an application under section 132 11  of the Income-Tax Act, 1961, and that application is pending before the Central Board of Direct Taxes, New Delhi if the Central Board of Direct Taxes gives its decision in that application , the order of the 1st respondent would get merged in that decision and the decision of the Central Board of Direct Taxes can be challenging in this Court. Hence, this Court has jurisdiction to entertain this petition. In this connection he placed reliance on the decision of the Supreme Court in Collector of Customs v. East India Commercial Co. Ltd. Calcutta, . We are unable to agree with Mr. Sharma that the rule laid down in that case bears on the point under consideration.

issues.text: Whether the relief declaring that the third respondent has no jurisdiction to hear the application under section 132(11) confers jurisdiction on this Court

anchor.surface_text: It was urged on behalf of the petitioner that one of the reliefs asked by him is to declare that the 3rd respondent had no jurisdiction to hear the application filed by him under Section 132 11  to that relief the 3rd respondent is a necessary party, that respondents office is in Delhi hence this Court has jurisdiction of the 3rd respondent. By that device, he cannot be permitted to impose jurisdiction on this Court.

issues.text: Whether the Central Government is a necessary party due to liability to pay interest under Section 132A(4)(a)

anchor.surface_text: Yet one other contention taken by Mr. Sharma was that under Section 132A 4  a , the Central Government is liable to pay interest on the assets retained under sub-section  5  of section 132, and, therefore, the Central Government is a necessary party to the proceeding.

arguments.claim: Challenging vires of s.132(5) Income-tax Act makes Central Government necessary party as only authority interested in defending vires

anchor.surface_text: The next companytention taken by Mr. Sharma, learned companynsel for the petitioner, is that as in this petition the petitioner is challenging the vires of S. 132 5  of the Income-Tax Act, 1961, the Central Government is a necessary party to such a proceeding. ... Mr. Sharma urged that the only authority, which is interested in defending the vires of a Central Act, is the Central Government and, therefore, the Central Government is a necessary party to a proceeding in which the vires of that Act or any provision therein, is challenged.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: estion as is referred to in clause  1  of Article 132 read with Article 147 of the Constitution if the Attorney General for India or the Advocate-Gene

arguments.court_reasoning: No law requires Central Govt as party to vires challenge; O.27A CPC requires notice to AG but not joinder as party unless AG applies; not practice in courts; distinguishes Allahabad HC, follows Rajasthan HC

arguments.claim: Order 27A CPC R.1 requires notice to AG on constitutional questions but does not make Central Govt necessary party; R.2 allows addition only if AG applies

anchor.surface_text: It is prescribed in R. 1 of O. 27A of the Civil Procedure Code that in any suit in which it appears to the Court that any such question as is referred in clause  1  of Article 132 read with Article 147 of the Constitution, is involved, the Court shall not proceed to determine that question until after notice has been given to the Attorney General for India ... Rule 2 of that Order provides that the Court may at any stage of the proceedings order that the Central Government or a State Government shall be added as a defendant ... if the Attorney General for India ... applies for such addition ... These provisions make it clear that the Central Government ... is number a necessary party to a proceeding wherein the vires of any provision of law is challenged.

arguments.claim: In Swadeshi Cotton Mills, State must be impleaded for vires challenge (Allahabad HC)

anchor.surface_text: In support of his companytention that the Central Government is a necessary party to this petition, Mr. Sharma invited our attention to the decision of the Allahabad High Court in Swadeshi Cotton Mills Co. Ltd. v Sales Tax Officer, . In paragraph 31 of the judgment. It is observed, thus- The petitioner has number impleaded the State of Uttar Pradesh as a party to the writ petition. In the absence of the State, the petitioner cannot be permitted to challenge the validity of the U. P. Taxation Laws Amendment Act, 1963.

arguments.claim: Union of India need not be impleaded for vires challenge if no relief against it; notice to AG sufficient (Rajasthan HC in Syed Hussain Ali)

anchor.surface_text: On the other hand, we are in agreement with the view expressed by the Rajasthan High Court in Syed Hussain Ali v. The Durgah Committee, Ajmer, . In paragraph 75 of the judgment, Papna, Ag, C. J., speaking for the Court, observed that- A companytention was also raised by the respondents that as the vires of a Central Act were being challenged, the Union of India should have been impleaded as a party. This argument has numberforce. The petitioners do number claim any relief against the Central Government.

That being so, the reliefs prayed for in the petition, whether companysidered under sub-Article  1  of Article 226 or under Sub-Article  2  of Article 226, prima facie, fall outside the jurisdiction of this Court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: All material events and parties located in Bombay determine territorial jurisdiction under Art 226

anchor.surface_text: In support of his companytention that the Central Government is a necessary party to this petition, Mr. Sharma invited our attention to the decision of the Allahabad High Court in Swadeshi Cotton Mills Co. Ltd. v Sales Tax Officer, . In paragraph 31 of the judgment. It is observed, thus- The petitioner has number impleaded the State of Uttar Pradesh as a party to the writ petition.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No reason given in that judgment

holdings.text: Rajasthan HC in Syed Hussain Ali correctly holds Union need not be impleaded for vires challenge absent relief against it; notice to AG sufficient

anchor.surface_text: On the other hand, we are in agreement with the view expressed by the Rajasthan High Court in Syed Hussain Ali v. The Durgah Committee, Ajmer, . In paragraph 75 of the judgment, Papna, Ag, C. J., speaking for the Court, observed that- A companytention was also raised by the respondents that as the vires of a Central Act were being challenged, the Union of India should have been impleaded as a party.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Agrees with reasoning that no relief against govt suffices

holdings.text: Merger doctrine does not apply as no order passed by appellate authority (CBDT); inferior order does not merge until appellate order made

anchor.surface_text: The next companytention, urged by Mr. Sharma in support of his companytention is that as against the decision of the 1st respondent, his client has filed an application under section 132 11  of the Income-Tax Act, 1961, and that application is pending before the Central Board of Direct Taxes, New Delhi if the Central Board of Direct Taxes gives its decision in that application , the order of the 1st respondent would get merged in that decision

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes Supreme Court in Collector of Customs: merger only when appellate order made; no appeal against authorisation anyway

holdings.text: Petitioner cannot confer jurisdiction by seeking declaration against 3rd respondent's jurisdiction over s.132(11) application merely because its office in Delhi

anchor.surface_text: It was urged on behalf of the petitioner that one of the reliefs asked by him is to declare that the 3rd respondent had numberjurisdiction to hear the application filed by him under Section 132 11  to that relief the 3rd respondent is a necessary party, that respondents office is in Delhi hence this Court has jurisdiction of the 3rd respondent.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Such device not permitted; can withdraw application

holdings.text: Central Government not necessary party due to s.132A(4)(a) liability for interest as no relief claimed under that provision

anchor.surface_text: Yet one other companytention taken by Mr. Sharma was that under Section 132A 4  a , the Central Government is liable to pay interest on the assets retained under sub-section  5  of section 132, and, therefore, the Central Government is a necessary party to the proceeding.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Reliefs dehors s.132A; challenging s.132(5) vires does not invoke it

holdings.text: This Court has no jurisdiction to entertain this petition

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons mentioned above, we are of the opinion that this Court has numberjurisdiction to entertain this petition. In that view we have number gone into the merits of the case.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative reasons on cause of action and parties lead to no jurisdiction

anchor.surface_text: This petition is, accordingly, dismissed with companyts. Advocates fee Rs.

precedents.cited_holding: The petitioner has not impleaded the State of Uttar Pradesh as a party to the writ petition. In the absence of the State, the petitioner cannot be permitted to challenge the validity of the U. P. Taxation Laws Amendment Act, 1963.

anchor.surface_text: It may be numbered that the searches and the seizures in question have taken place in the city of Bombay. Respondents 1 and 2 reside in that city. Their offices are situate in that city. Even the petitioner is residing in that city. The authorisation issued by the 1st respondent under section 132 1  was issued in that city, therefore, prima facie, the entire cause of action has arisen in the city of Bombay. That being so, the reliefs prayed for in the petition, whether companysidered under sub-Article  1  of Article 226 or under Sub-Article  2  of Article 226, prima facie, fall outside the jurisdiction of this Court.
This petition is, accordingly, dismissed with companyts. Advocates fee Rs.

It was urged on behalf of the petitioner that to this petition the Central Government is a necessary party, and, therefore, this Court has jurisdiction to entertain this petition. If the Central Government is a necessary party to this petition, then this Court would have jurisdiction to entertain this petition. Therefore, we have to see whether the Central Government is a necessary party to this petition.
This petition is, accordingly, dismissed with companyts. Advocates fee Rs.

Undoubtedly, the Central Government is number a necessary party to the reliefs prayed for as against respondents 1 and 2. That much was number disputed before us. But what was said on behalf of the petitioner is that the money seized by the 2nd respondent at any rate that portion of the money, that had been appropriated towards the tax due from the petitioner, has number gone to the Consolidated Fund of India.
This petition is, accordingly, dismissed with companyts. Advocates fee Rs.

The next companytention taken by Mr. Sharma, learned companynsel for the petitioner, is that as in this petition the petitioner is challenging the vires of S. 132 5  of the Income-Tax Act, 1961, the Central Government is a necessary party to such a proceeding. We have number to see whether that companytention can be upheld.
This petition is, accordingly, dismissed with companyts. Advocates fee Rs.

It is prescribed in R. 1 of O. 27A of the Civil Procedure Code that in any suit in which it appears to the Court that any such question as is referred in clause  1  of Article 132 read with Article 147 of the Constitution, is involved, the Court shall not proceed to determine that question until after notice has been given to the Attorney General for India
This petition is, accordingly, dismissed with companyts. Advocates fee Rs.

In support of his companytention that the Central Government is a necessary party to this petition, Mr. Sharma invited our attention to the decision of the Allahabad High Court in Swadeshi Cotton Mills Co. Ltd. v Sales Tax Officer, . In paragraph 31 of the judgment. It is observed, thus- The petitioner has number impleaded the State of Uttar Pradesh as a party to the writ petition.
This petition is, accordingly, dismissed with companyts. Advocates fee Rs.

On the other hand, we are in agreement with the view expressed by the Rajasthan High Court in Syed Hussain Ali v. The Durgah Committee, Ajmer, . In paragraph 75 of the judgment, Papna, Ag, C. J., speaking for the Court, observed that- A companytention was also raised by the respondents that as the vires of a Central Act were being challenged, the Union of India should have been impleaded as a party.
This petition is, accordingly, dismissed with companyts. Advocates fee Rs.
